filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English. To find out more, visit our website.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: Amazon is so successful it affects how many of us live our lives, so in this programme we'll be taking a look inside the brain of Jeff Bezos to find out how he thinks. When Jeff Bezos' friends talk about him, three words they often use are invention, risk-taking and long-term vision.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: As a boy, Jeff and his grandfather repaired an old, broken-down truck. When interviewed today, Bezos sometimes compares Amazon to that truck – very heavy, but impossible to stop when it rolls downhill, which is exactly what accidentally happened one day.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: What happened when the young Jeff Bezos' car accidentally rolled downhill? Was it a. Jeff jumped in and pulled the handbrake? b. Jeff's grandad lost a thumb? or c. Jeff's hair fell out? Well, Jeff Bezos is bald, so maybe it's c. His hair fell out. OK, Georgina, we'll find out later. As a company, Amazon has been remarkably strong. It survived the dot-com crash of 2000 and saw profits jump during the
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: Covid pandemic as more and more people started shopping online. Retail analyst Natalie Berg thinks Amazon's success is due to its customer strategy, as she explains to BBC Radio 4 programme Seriously.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: Natalie thinks that Amazon put customers at the heart of their business – in other words they make customers the most important part.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: In the difficult years following the dot-com crash, Jeff Bezos started Marketplace, where other sellers compete with Amazon's own products. More sellers brought more customers, which in turn brought down prices.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: Most recently, Jeff Bezos has set his sights on even bigger things, saving the future of the planet. Bezos chose Tom Rivet-Karnak of the environmental group Global Optimism to help Amazon meet climate initiative goals aimed at slowing climate change. Here is Tom Rivet-Karnak telling David Baker, presenter of BBC Radio 4 Seriously, about his conversation with Jeff Bezos.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: Protecting the planet is what Jeff Bezos wants to be part of his legacy – the achievements of his life that will continue after he dies.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: Bezos wants to be on the right side of history, judged to have acted correctly or morally by future generations. Ultimately though, it's real action on climate change that counts, not just greenwashing. Do you know this new expression, Georgina? Well, I know that whitewashing means trying to hide the truth about something. Right, so greenwashing means trying to make people believe that your company is doing more to protect the environment than it really is. Well, with so many achievements already
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: behind him, I'm sure Jeff has made his grandparents very proud, which reminds me of your quiz question, Neil. Ah, yes. I asked Georgina what happened when the car Jeff Bezos and his granddad Lawrence were fixing accidentally rolled downhill. I thought it was C – that Jeff lost all his hair. Was I right? No, you were wrong, I'm afraid, Georgina. The correct answer was that B – his grandfather lost his thumb. OK, Neil. Let's recap the vocabulary.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: If you put something at the heart of things, you make it the most important part. Your legacy means all your life achievements that will continue after your death. Someone who's on the right side of history will be judged positively by future generations.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json

chunks.chunk_text: That's all for our peek inside the brain of the world's richest man. Join us again next time when we'll be discussing another trending topic. Bye for now! Goodbye!
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Inside the head of Jeff Bezos.json
